Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: RUI:Applications and New Techniques for Exact Parameterized Computation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Efficient algorithms are fundamental to various areas in computer science. This project will study new techniques for designing efficient algorithms for hard combinatorial problems. The interaction between theoretical analysis and practical implementations of such hard problems will be explored. Furthermore, this project will advance the study of algorithms and systems in a minority-serving institution where under-represented students will gain valuable experience in foundational cutting-edge research.

More precisely, this project will investigate novel measures for some classical and important NP-hard problems, algebraic techniques for designing exact and parameterized algorithms, and parallel/distributed implementations of exact and parameterized algorithms. The first part is devoted to studying the effects of new measures on designing algorithms for well-known NP-hard problems such as the Boolean Satisfiability Problem. The second part is focused on expanding the power of algebraic techniques to those seemingly difficult problems involving vertex deletion. The last part is to devise a clever way to implement resulting algorithms on a parallel/multi-core machines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the techniques of algebra and novel measures, and applied these techniques to design new efficient algorithms for the Feedback Vertex Set problem and the Multivariate Polynomials problem. These techniques helped to achieve better complexity bounds for the new algorithms. So our studies have advanced theoretical research on algorithm design and analysis for NP-hard problems. Such advancements are significant due to the wide applications of NP-hard problems.

This project also developed a software which implements four well known serial algorithms and one parallel algorithm (MPI) for the Maximum Clique problem. The Maximum Clique problem has many applications in bioinformatics, coding theory, economics, etc. Therefore it is important to find an optimal solution to the Maximum Clique problem as fast as possible. This project shows that parallelization is an effective way to speed up the search of an optimal solution to the Maximum Clique problem. The software from this project achieved a speedup of 90 times faster with 200 CPUs for a DIMACS benchmark. Such a speedup significantly reduces the time to find optimal solutions to the Maximum Clique problem. The software from this project provides a foundation for other researchers to study and improve the algorithms for the Maximum Clique problem and is a tool for other researchers to solve their research problems.

Three undergraduate students and two graduate students participated in this project which had a great impact on them. The students gained research experience on algorithm design and analysis from this project. One under-represented undergraduate student worked on this project for about one year. His participation in this project led him to graduate school. He acknowledged that this project gave him a very strong advantage in academic work, career prospects, and quality of life.
